subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New Zealand dialect
msgSnippet: ... No, that would be a *phonetic* mapping, one based directly on particular sounds.  Phonemes are *abstractions* at the sound level, and only become concrete
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> > (Heh, heh.) They're actually equivalent; with the exception of the
> > special cases BATH and CLOTH, the lexical sets correspond to phonemes.
>
> So it will still be It-Key-See-Et-No-Tea?

No, that would be a *phonetic* mapping, one based directly on particular
sounds. Phonemes are *abstractions* at the sound level, and only become
concrete when you look at what sounds alike and what sounds differently
(which is the purpose of the lexical sets).

> > They're just easier to grasp: people find it easier to think about
> >lexical sets
> >...
> >(Snicker, snicker.)
>
> Now you're joking.

Well, yes and no; that is, I do mean what I say: lexical-set mappings
are equivalent to phonemic (as opposed to phonetic) mappings.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
The present impossibility of giving a scientific explanation is no proof
that there is no scientific explanation. The unexplained is not to be
identified with the unexplainable, and the strange and extraordinary
nature of a fact is not a justification for attributing it to powers
above nature. --The Catholic Encyclopedia, s.v. "telepathy" (1913)
